quote: The Resurrection was the greatest ‘eucatastrophe’ possible in the greatest Fairy Story — and produces that essential emotion: Christian joy which produces tears because it is qualitatively so like sorrow, because it comes from those places where Joy and Sorrow are at one, reconciled, as selfishness and altruism are lost in Love.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: The Resurrection was the greatest ‘eucatastrophe’ possible in the greatest Fairy Story — and produces that essential emotion: Christian joy which produces tears because it is qualitatively so like sorrow, because it comes from those places where Joy and Sorrow are at one, reconciled, as selfishness and altruism are lost in Love.
summary: J.R.R. Tolkien explains that Jesus's Resurrection is the ultimate "eucatastrophe" – a sudden, miraculous, and joyful turning point or happy ending in the grand story of Christianity. This event produces a unique "Christian joy" that is so profound it often brings tears. These tears aren't from sadness, but because this deep joy is intimately connected with sorrow, emerging from a place where both emotions are reconciled and become one. It's a transformative experience, much like how individual ideas of selfishness and altruism are transcended and unified within the greater power of Love.

quote: Kings built tombs more splendid than the houses of the living and counted the names of their descent dearer than the names of their sons. Childless lords sat in aged halls musing on heraldry or in high cold towers asking questions of the stars. And so the kingdom of Gondor sank into ruin, the line of kings failed, the white tree withered and the rule of Gondor was given over to lesser men.

summary: This quote explains that the kingdom of Gondor declined because its rulers had misplaced priorities. Kings cared more about building elaborate tombs for the dead and valuing their family history than they did about the well-being of the living or their own children. Lords, many of whom had no heirs, spent their time idly pondering old family symbols or asking questions of the stars, rather than actively governing. This obsession with the past and neglect of the present led to Gondor's downfall: its royal line died out, its symbolic "white tree" withered, and the rule was eventually taken over by less capable men.

However, Sméagol, ever particular, rejects the idea of "chips," preferring only the plain fish and calling the cooked potatoes "nasty." Frustrated by Sméagol's stubbornness, Sam gives up.

quote: Bilbo almost stopped breathing, and went stiff himself. He was desperate. He must get away, out of this horrible darkness, while he had any strength left. He must fight. He must stab the foul thing, put its eyes out, kill it. It meant to kill him. No, not a fair fight. He was invisible now. Gollum had no sword. Gollum had not actually threatened to kill him, or tried yet. And he was miserable, alone, lost. A sudden understanding, a pity mixed with horror, welled up in Bilbo’s heart: a glimpse of endless unmarked days without light or hope of betterment, hard stone, cold fish, sneaking and whispering.

A wave of pity mixed with horror washed over Bilbo as he imagined Gollum's bleak, endless existence in the darkness, full of only cold fish and sneaking around, with no hope for anything better.

quote:
Upon the hearth the fire is red,
Beneath the roof there is a bed;
But not yet weary are our feet,
Still round the corner we may meet
A sudden tree or standing stone
That none have seen but we alone.
Tree and flower, leaf and grass,
Let them pass! Let them pass!
Hill and water under sky,
Pass them by! Pass them by!

Still round the corner there may wait
A new road or a secret gate,
And though we pass them by today,
Tomorrow we may come this way
And take the hidden paths that run
Towards the Moon or to the Sun.
Apple, thorn, and nut and sloe,
Let them go! Let them go!
Sand and stone and pool and dell,
Fare you well! Fare you well!

Home is behind, the world ahead,
And there are many paths to tread
Through shadows to the edge of night,
Until the stars are all alight.
Then world behind and home ahead,
We'll wander back to home and bed.
Mist and twilight, cloud and shade,
Away shall fade! Away shall fade!
Fire and lamp and meat and bread,
And then to bed! And then to bed!

summary: This quote describes "Romance" not necessarily as romantic love, but as a sudden, unexpected, and miraculous blessing that you can't count on experiencing again. In this way, it acts like good news, offering a fleeting but powerful glimpse of profound Joy—a Joy that feels otherworldly and is as deeply moving and bittersweet as grief itself.

prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: The strongest must seek a way, say you? But I say: let a ploughman plough, but choose an otter for swimming, and for running light over grass and leaf, or over snow- an Elf!
summary: The speaker disagrees with the idea that the strongest person is always the one who will find a solution or be best suited for every task. Instead, they argue that it's crucial to choose the right individual or creature based on their natural abilities for a specific job. They illustrate this by saying you should let a farmer do the ploughing, pick an otter for swimming, and choose an Elf for light, swift movement over natural terrain or snow. Essentially, the message is that different tasks require different inherent talents, and it's always best to use someone (or something) naturally suited for the job rather than relying on general strength.

quote: Far over the misty mountains cold. To dungeons deep, and caverns old

quote: I stand in Minas Anor, the Tower of the Sun; and behold! the Shadow has departed! I will be a Shieldmaiden no longer, nor vie with the great Riders, nor take joy only in the songs of slaying. I will be a healer, and love all things that grow and are not barren.

Essentially, Gandalf has now taken on the powerful, good leadership role that Saruman failed to fulfill.

quote: There, peeping among the cloud-wrack above a dark tor high up in the mountains, Sam saw a white star twinkle for a while. The beauty of it smote his heart, as he looked up out of the forsaken land, and hope returned to him. For like a shaft, clear and cold, the thought pierced him that in the end the Shadow was only a small and passing thing: there was a light and high beauty for ever beyond its reach. His song in the Tower had been defiance rather than hope; for then he was thinking of himself. Now, for a moment, his own fate, and even his master’s, ceased to trouble him. He crawled back into the brambles and laid himself by Frodo’s side, and putting away all fear he cast himself into a deep untroubled sleep.

quote: Yet at the last Beren was slain by the Wolf that came from the gates of Angband, and he died in the arms of Tinúviel. quote:
wandering in the summer in the woods of Neldoreth [Beren] came upon Lúthien, daughter of Thingol and Melian, at a time of evening under moonrise, as she danced upon the unfading grass in the glades beside Esgalduin. Then all memory of his pain departed from him, and he fell into an enchantment; for Lúthien was the most beautiful of all the Children of Ilúvatar. Blue was her raiment as the unclouded heaven, but her eyes were grey as the starlit evening; her mantle was sewn with golden flowers, but her hair was dark as the shadows of twilight. As the light upon the leaves of trees, as the voice of clear waters, as the stars above the mists of the world, such was her glory and her loveliness; and in her face was a shining light.

But she vanished from his sigh; and he became dumb, as one that is bound under a spell, and he strayed long in the woods, wild and wary as a beast, seeking for her. In his heart he called her Tinúviel, that signifies Nightingale, daughter of twilight, in the Grey-elven tongue, for he knew no other name for her. And he saw her afar as leaves in the winds of autumn, and in winter as a star upon a hill, but a chain was upon his limbs.

summary: One summer evening, as Beren wandered through the woods, he came upon Lúthien dancing in a moonlit clearing. However, she soon vanished from his sight, leaving him speechless and heartbroken. He spent a long time searching for her like a wild animal, calling her Tinúviel, which means Nightingale. Though he would sometimes catch glimpses of her from a distance, he felt an invisible chain preventing him from reaching her.

quote:
Legolas watched them for awhile with a smile upon his lips, and then he turned to the others. 'The strongest must seek a way, say you? But I say: let a ploughman plough, but choose an otter for swimming, and for running light over grass and leaf, or over snow--an Elf.'

With that he sprang forth nimbly, and then Frodo noticed as if for the first time, though he had long known it, that the Elf had no boots, but wore only light shoes, as he always did, and his feet made little imprint in the snow.

'Farewell!' he said to Gandalf. 'I go to find the Sun!' Then swift as a runner over firm sand he shot away, and quickly overtaking the toiling men, with a wave of his hand he passed them, and sped into the distance, and vanished round the rocky turn.

'Farewell!' he said to Gandalf. 'I go to find the Sun!' Then swift as a runner over firm sand he shot away, and quickly overtaking the toiling men, with a wave of his hand he passed them, and sped into the distance, and vanished round the rocky turn.
summary: Legolas, smiling, shared his view that everyone has a specific strength: a farmer should farm, an otter should swim, and an Elf is best for moving lightly and swiftly over any terrain, even snow. He then demonstrated this by springing forth, and Frodo noticed he wore only light shoes, leaving hardly any mark. Announcing he was off "to find the Sun," Legolas then sped away with incredible speed, easily passing the other men and quickly disappearing into the distance.

quote: And that's the way of a real tale. Take any one that you're fond of. You may know, or guess, what kind of a tale it is, happy-ending or sad-ending, but the people in it don't know. And you don't want them to.

The quote suggests that this is how it should be, and you wouldn't want them to know, because their journey, struggles, and hopes in the face of uncertainty are what make the tale compelling and real.

quote: Let us remember that a traitor may betray himself and do good that he does not intend.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Let us remember that a traitor may betray himself and do good that he does not intend.

Even more surprisingly, their malicious actions might unintentionally bring about positive outcomes for the very people or cause they sought to betray, perhaps by revealing a weakness that then gets fixed, or by uniting others against them. So, a traitor's bad deeds can sometimes, without their intention, lead to good results for others.

quote: For so sworn good or evil an oath may not be broken and it shall pursue oathkeeper and oathbreaker to the world's end.

quote: For you do not yet know the strengths of your hearts, and you cannot foresee what each may meet on the road.

They argue that they are a very skilled cook themselves, and their main point is that their talent for *preparing* food for others is far greater than their value or appeal if *they themselves* were to be cooked and eaten. In essence, they are suggesting that they would be much more useful alive as a chef than dead as a meal.

quote: The doom of the Elves is to be immortal, to love the beauty of the world, to bring it to full flower with their gifts of delicacy and perfection, to last while it lasts, never leaving it even when ‘slain’, but returning – and yet, when the Followers come, to teach them, and make way for them, to ‘fade’ as the Followers grow and absorb the life from which both proceed. The Doom (or the Gift) of Men is mortality, freedom from the circles of the world.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: The doom of the Elves is to be immortal, to love the beauty of the world, to bring it to full flower with their gifts of delicacy and perfection, to last while it lasts, never leaving it even when ‘slain’, but returning – and yet, when the Followers come, to teach them, and make way for them, to ‘fade’ as the Followers grow and absorb the life from which both proceed. The Doom (or the Gift) of Men is mortality, freedom from the circles of the world.
summary: This quote describes the distinct destinies of Elves and Men. Elves are immortal, meaning they live forever and are deeply connected to the world, loving its beauty and helping it thrive. They are bound to it always, even returning after death. However, their ultimate role is to teach and make way for humans, gradually fading as humanity grows and absorbs the life from the world. In contrast, humans are mortal, and this mortality is presented as both their fate and a gift, freeing them from the endless cycles of the world that bind the Elves.

quote: Evidently we look so much alike that your desire to make an incurable dent in my hat must be excused.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Evidently we look so much alike that your desire to make an incurable dent in my hat must be excused.
summary: The speaker is telling someone that because they look so much alike, it's understandable why the other person might have wanted to hit them (or their hat) so hard it would leave a permanent mark. Essentially, the speaker is forgiving the other person's aggressive intent, assuming it was a case of mistaken identity and they thought the speaker was someone else.

quote: I wish life was not so short,' he thought. 'Languages take such a time, and so do all the things one wants to know about.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: I wish life was not so short,' he thought. 'Languages take such a time, and so do all the things one wants to know about.
summary: The quote expresses the speaker's wish that life wasn't so short. They feel there isn't enough time to learn everything they want, specifically mentioning that mastering languages takes a lot of time, and this applies to all the other knowledge and experiences they wish to acquire. Essentially, they regret that life is too brief to satisfy their desire for extensive learning and understanding.

quote: Who knows? Have patience. Go where you must go, and hope!
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Who knows? Have patience. Go where you must go, and hope!
summary: This quote advises us to accept that we don't always know what the future holds. It encourages us to be patient and not rush things, but also to take action and follow the path we need to go on. Ultimately, it tells us to maintain hope and a positive outlook, even when facing the unknown.

quote: Never laugh at live dragons, Bilbo you fool!' he said to himself, and it became a favourite saying of his later, and passed into a proverb. 'You aren't nearly through this adventure yet,' he added, and that was pretty true as well.

This important lesson became his favorite saying and eventually a common proverb. He also understood that his challenging adventure was far from over, with many more difficulties still ahead of him.

quote: Gandalf thought of most things; and though he could not do everything, he could do a great deal for friends in a tight corner.

While he wasn't all-powerful and couldn't solve every problem, he was still incredibly capable and could provide significant help to his friends, especially when they were in a difficult or dangerous situation.

quote: As she stood before Aragorn she paused suddenly and looked upon him, and her eyes were shining. And he looked down upon her fair face and smiled; but as he took the cup, his hand met hers, and he knew that she trembled at the touch.

quote: No, my heart will not yet despair. Gandalf fell and has returned and is with us. We may stand, if only on one leg, or at least be left still upon our knees.

quote: For a while they stood there, like men on the edge of a sleep where nightmare lurks, holding it off, though they know that they can only come to morning through the shadows.

quote: Elrond's house was perfect, whether you liked food or sleep or story-telling or singing (or reading), or just sitting and thinking best, or a pleasant mixture of them all. Merely to be there was a cure for weariness. ... Evil things did not come into the secret valley of Rivendell.

quote: When the glamour wears off, or merely works a bit thin, they think they have made a mistake, and that the real soul-mate is still to find. . . And of course they are as a rule quite right: they did make a mistake. Only a very wise man at the end of his life could make a sound judgment concerning whom, amongst the total chances, he ought most profitably to have married! Nearly all marriages, even happy ones, are mistakes: in the sense that almost certainly (in a more perfect world, or even with a little more care in this very imperfect one) both partners might have found more suitable mates. But the 'real soul-mate' is the one you are actually married to.

summary: When the initial excitement and newness of a relationship fade, people often feel they made the wrong choice and that their true soulmate is still waiting to be found. The author agrees that they likely did make a mistake, not in choosing a specific person, but because it's nearly impossible for anyone to perfectly select the absolute best partner for themselves out of all possibilities. Most marriages, even happy ones, could be considered "mistakes" in the sense that, in a more ideal world, both partners might have found someone even more perfectly suited. However, the core message is that your "real soulmate" isn't some ideal person you need to find, but rather the person you are actually married to.

quote: Aure entuluva! day shall come again!

It means that even after periods of darkness, difficulty, or despair, brighter times are inevitable. It reassures us that just as night gives way to day, challenges will eventually pass, and a new, better beginning will arrive. It's a declaration of faith in the future, reminding us not to give up, as good things are always on their way.

quote: Fire, fear, foes! Awake!
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Fire, fear, foes! Awake!

The urgent command "Awake!" then tells us to snap out of any inaction or unawareness. It's a strong plea to become alert, confront these threats, and rise to the challenge instead of being paralyzed by fear or ignorance.

quote:
Now, therefore, I will sleep. I speak no comfort to you, for there is no comfort for such pain within the circles of the world. The uttermost choice is before you: to repent and go to the Havens and bear away into the West the memory of our days together that shall there be evergreen but never more than memory; or else to abide the Doom of Men."

Nay, dear lord," she said, "that choice is long over. There is now no ship that would bear me hence, and I must indeed abide the Doom of Men, whether I will or I nill: the loss and the silence. But I say to you, King of the Numenoreans, not till now have I understood the tale of your people and their fall. As wicked fools I scorned them, but I pity them at last. For if this is indeed, as the Eldar say, the gift of the One to Men, it is bitter to receive."

So it seems," he said. "But let us not be overthrown at the final test, who of old renounced the Shadow and the Ring. In sorrow we must go, but not in despair. Behold! we are not bound for ever to the circles of the world, and beyond them is more than memory.

Having overcome great evils in the past, he believes they are not bound to this world forever, and there is something more profound than mere memory awaiting them beyond death.

quote: I have in this War a burning private grudge—which would probably make me a better soldier at 49 than I was at 22: against that ruddy little ignoramus Adolf Hitler (for the odd thing about demonic inspiration and impetus is that it in no way enhances the purely intellectual stature: it chiefly affects the mere will). quote: The chief purpose of life, for any of us, is to increase according to our capacity our knowledge of God by all means we have, and to be moved by it to praise and thanks.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: The chief purpose of life, for any of us, is to increase according to our capacity our knowledge of God by all means we have, and to be moved by it to praise and thanks.
summary: According to this quote, the most important reason for anyone's life is to continuously deepen their understanding of God, using every possible method and resource they have. The goal is that this growing knowledge will then move them to express feelings of praise and gratitude.

quote: Do not trouble your hearts overmuch with thought of the road tonight. Maybe the paths that you shall each tread are already laid before your feet, though you do not see them.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Do not trouble your hearts overmuch with thought of the road tonight. Maybe the paths that you shall each tread are already laid before your feet, though you do not see them.
summary: This quote encourages you not to worry too much about what lies ahead or the journey you'll take. It suggests that the paths you will follow might already be decided for you, even if you can't see them yet.

quote: The doom lies in yourself, not in your name.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: The doom lies in yourself, not in your name.
summary: This quote means that your ultimate failure or misfortune, or your "doom," comes from within you – from your own character, choices, and actions – rather than from external factors like your family name, reputation, or how others perceive you. It emphasizes that your destiny is shaped by who you are and what you do, not by your background or the labels society puts on you. In essence, if things go wrong, the responsibility lies with your own decisions and inner self, not with your name or any pre-determined fate.

quote: Muchos de los que viven merecen morir y algunos de los que mueren merecen la vida. ¿Puedes devolver la vida? Entonces no te apresures a dispensar la muerte, pues ni el más sabio conoce el fin de todos los caminos.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Muchos de los que viven merecen morir y algunos de los que mueren merecen la vida. ¿Puedes devolver la vida? Entonces no te apresures a dispensar la muerte, pues ni el más sabio conoce el fin de todos los caminos.
summary: This quote suggests that life and death are not always justly distributed: some people who live might deserve to die, while some who have died might have deserved to live. Since we cannot bring someone back to life once they are gone, the quote advises against being quick to decide who should die. It emphasizes that even the wisest person doesn't know the full consequences or future of a life, urging caution and humility before making irreversible decisions about someone's fate.

quote: And so they stood on the walls of the City of Gondor, and a great wind rose and blew, and their hair, raven and golden, streamed out mingling in the air.

quote:
The stars are far brighter
Than gems without measure,
The moon is far whiter

Given these superior joys and wonders available right where one is, the poem questions why anyone would feel the need to wander far away. Ultimately, it's a warm invitation for those who have left to come back to the familiar comfort and true richness of their "Valley."

quote:

Thy starlight on the Western Seas.

o menel aglar elenath!

They sing to her and call upon her, cherishing the enduring memory of her starlight and beauty, despite their physical separation, expressing deep reverence and a sense of longing for her presence.

quote:
Studies [on the origin of fairy-stories] are, however, scientific (at least in intent); they are the pursuit of folklorists or anthropologists: that is of people using the stories not as they were meant to be used, but as a quarry from which to dig evidence, or information, about matters in which they are interested.

...with regard to fairy stories, I feel that it is more interesting, and also in its way more difficult, to consider what they are, what they have become for us, and what values the long alchemic processes of time have produced in them. In Dasent's words I would say: 'We must be satisfied with the soup that is set before us, and not desire to see the bones of the ox out of which it has been boiled.'

Such stories have now a mythical or total (unanalysable) effect, an effect quite independent of the findings of Comparative Folk-lore, and one which it cannot spoil or explain; they open a door on Other Time, and if we pass through, though only for a moment, we stand outside our own time, outside Time itself, maybe.

Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Studies [on the origin of fairy-stories] are, however, scientific (at least in intent); they are the pursuit of folklorists or anthropologists: that is of people using the stories not as they were meant to be used, but as a quarry from which to dig evidence, or information, about matters in which they are interested.

...with regard to fairy stories, I feel that it is more interesting, and also in its way more difficult, to consider what they are, what they have become for us, and what values the long alchemic processes of time have produced in them. In Dasent's words I would say: 'We must be satisfied with the soup that is set before us, and not desire to see the bones of the ox out of which it has been boiled.'

Such stories have now a mythical or total (unanalysable) effect, an effect quite independent of the findings of Comparative Folk-lore, and one which it cannot spoil or explain; they open a door on Other Time, and if we pass through, though only for a moment, we stand outside our own time, outside Time itself, maybe.
summary: The author suggests that while academics often study fairy tales scientifically, treating them as a source of historical or cultural information, this approach misses the true essence of the stories. Instead, he believes it's more valuable to appreciate what these tales have become over time and the profound impact they have on us today. He suggests we should enjoy the stories for what they are, much like enjoying a finished soup without needing to see the bones it was made from. Ultimately, fairy tales possess a unique, almost magical power that goes beyond scientific explanation; they can transport us out of our own time and into another realm.

quote: But I suppose it’s often that way. The brave things in the old tales and songs, Mr. Frodo: adventures, as I used to call them. I used to think that they were things the wonderful folk of the stories went out and looked for, because they wanted them, because they were exciting and life was a bit dull, a kind of a sport, as you might say. But that’s not the way of it with the tales that really mattered, or the ones that stay in the mind. Folk seem to have been just landed in them, usually – their paths were laid that way, as you put it. But I expect they had lots of chances, like us, of turning back, only they didn’t. And if they had, we shouldn’t know, because they’d have been forgotten. We hear about those as just went on – and not all to a good end, mind you; at least not to what folk inside a story and not outside it call a good end. You know, coming home, and finding things all right, though not quite the same – like old Mr. Bilbo. But those aren’t always the best tales to hear, though they may be the best tales to get landed in!

However, he now realizes that in the most significant and memorable tales, characters often don't go looking for adventure; instead, they find themselves thrust into them, as if their path was already set. He believes these individuals, like us, had many opportunities to turn back but chose not to, and that's why their stories are remembered. He also notes that not all such tales end happily, at least not in the traditional sense of returning home safely, but sometimes the most powerful stories to hear aren't the ones you'd necessarily want to live through yourself.

quote: There was Eru, the One, who in Arda is called Ilúvatar; and he made first the Ainur, the Holy Ones, that were the offspring of his thought, and they were with him before aught else was made. quote:
Yes, that's so,' said Sam. 'And we shouldn't be here at all, if we'd known more about it before we started. But I suppose it's often that way. The brave things in the old tales and songs, Mr. Frodo: adventures, as I used to call them. I used to think that they were things the wonderful folk of the stories went out and looked for, because they wanted them, because they were exciting and life was a bit dull, a kind of a sport, as you might say. But that's not the way of it with the tales that really mattered, or the ones that stay in the mind. Folk seem to have been just landed in them, usually – their paths were laid that way, as you put it. But I expect they had lots of chances, like us, of turning back, only they didn't. And if they had, we shouldn't know, because they'd have been forgotten. We hear about those as just went on – and not all to a good end, mind you; at least not to what folk inside a story and not outside it call a good end. You know, coming home, and finding things all right, though not quite the same – like old Mr Bilbo. But those aren't always the best tales to hear, though they may be the best tales to get landed in! I wonder what sort of a tale we've fallen into?'
'I wonder,' said Frodo. 'But I don't know. And that's the way of a real tale. Take any one that you're fond of. You may know, or guess, what kind of a tale it is, happy-ending or sad-ending, but the people in it don't know. And you don't want them to.'
'No, sir, of course not. Beren now, he never thought he was going to get that Silmaril from the Iron Crown in Thangorodrim, and yet he did, and that was a worse place and a blacker danger than ours. But that's a long tale, of course, and goes on past the happiness and into grief and beyond it – and the Silmaril went on and came to Eärendil. And why, sir, I never thought of that before! We've got – you've got some of the light of it in that star-glass that the Lady gave you! Why, to think of it, we're in the same tale still! It's going on. Don't the great tales never end?'
'No, they never end as tales,' said Frodo. 'But the people in them come, and go when their part's ended. Our part will end later – or sooner.

But that's not the way of it with the tales that really mattered, or the ones that stay in the mind. Folk seem to have been just landed in them, usually – their paths were laid that way, as you put it. But I expect they had lots of chances, like us, of turning back, only they didn't. And if they had, we shouldn't know, because they'd have been forgotten. We hear about those as just went on – and not all to a good end, mind you; at least not to what folk inside a story and not outside it call a good end. You know, coming home, and finding things all right, though not quite the same – like old Mr Bilbo. But those aren't always the best tales to hear, though they may be the best tales to get landed in! I wonder what sort of a tale we've fallen into?'
'I wonder,' said Frodo. 'But I don't know. And that's the way of a real tale. Take any one that you're fond of. You may know, or guess, what kind of a tale it is, happy-ending or sad-ending, but the people in it don't know. And you don't want them to.'
'No, sir, of course not. Beren now, he never thought he was going to get that Silmaril from the Iron Crown in Thangorodrim, and yet he did, and that was a worse place and a blacker danger than ours. But that's a long tale, of course, and goes on past the happiness and into grief and beyond it – and the Silmaril went on and came to Eärendil. And why, sir, I never thought of that before! We've got – you've got some of the light of it in that star-glass that the Lady gave you! Why, to think of it, we're in the same tale still! It's going on. Don't the great tales never end?'
'No, they never end as tales,' said Frodo. 'But the people in them come, and go when their part's ended. Our part will end later – or sooner.
summary: Sam and Frodo are discussing the true nature of adventures and stories. Sam initially thought that the brave deeds in old tales were exciting things people chose to seek out for fun, but he now realizes that people are often simply landed in these great adventures without knowing what lies ahead. He believes that the truly brave ones are those who choose not to turn back, even when they have the chance, and their perseverance is what makes them remembered in the "tales that really matter," even if the outcome isn't always a traditionally "happy" one for the characters involved. Frodo agrees, emphasizing that characters within a real story never know its ending, and that's part of what makes it a genuine tale. Sam then realizes their own journey might be part of an ancient, ongoing epic, like the tale of Beren. Frodo concludes by clarifying that while the great tales themselves never truly end, the people within them eventually complete their part and move on.

quote: Shall we mourn here deedless forever a shadow-folk mist-haunting dropping vain tears in the thankless sea
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Shall we mourn here deedless forever a shadow-folk mist-haunting dropping vain tears in the thankless sea

quote: It is not despair, for despair is only for those who see the end beyond all doubt. We do not. It is wisdom to recognize necessity, when all other courses have been weighed, though as folly it may appear to those who cling to false hope.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: It is not despair, for despair is only for those who see the end beyond all doubt. We do not. summary: This feeling isn't despair, because true despair only happens when you're absolutely convinced there's no hope left, and we aren't that certain. Instead, it's wisdom to accept what needs to be done, but only after thoroughly exploring all other possibilities. While this realistic choice might seem foolish to those who still cling to unrealistic or false hopes, it is, in fact, the smart path.

quote:
Man, Sub-creator, the refracted light
through whom is splintered from a single White
to many hues, and endlessly combined
in living shapes that move from mind to mind.
Though all the crannies of the world we filled
with Elves and Goblins, though we dared to build
Gods and their houses out of dark and light,
and sowed the seed of dragons, 'twas our right
(used or misused). The right has not decayed.
We make still by the law in which we're made.

The author asserts that this power to create is not just a skill, but an inherent and enduring right, fundamental to our very nature and the "law" by which we ourselves were made.

quote:
Fantasy is a natural human activity. It certainly does not destroy or even insult Reason; and it does not either blunt the appetite for, nor obscure the perception of, scientific verity. On the contrary. The keener and the clearer is the reason, the better fantasy will it make. If men were ever in a state in which they did not want to know or could not perceive truth (facts or evidence), then Fantasy would languish until they were cured. If they ever get into that state (it would not seem at all impossible), Fantasy will perish, and become Morbid Delusion.

For creative Fantasy is founded upon the hard recognition that things are so in the world as it appears under the sun; on a recognition of fact, but not a slavery to it. So upon logic was founded the nonsense that displays itself in the tales and rhymes of Lewis Carroll. If men really could not distinguish between frogs and men, fairy-stories about frog-kings would not have arisen.
prompt_template:
Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Fantasy is a natural human activity. It certainly does not destroy or even insult Reason; and it does not either blunt the appetite for, nor obscure the perception of, scientific verity. On the contrary. The keener and the clearer is the reason, the better fantasy will it make. If men were ever in a state in which they did not want to know or could not perceive truth (facts or evidence), then Fantasy would languish until they were cured. If they ever get into that state (it would not seem at all impossible), Fantasy will perish, and become Morbid Delusion.

For creative Fantasy is founded upon the hard recognition that things are so in the world as it appears under the sun; on a recognition of fact, but not a slavery to it. So upon logic was founded the nonsense that displays itself in the tales and rhymes of Lewis Carroll. If men really could not distinguish between frogs and men, fairy-stories about frog-kings would not have arisen.
summary: Fantasy is a natural human activity that doesn't harm our ability to reason or seek scientific truth. In fact, a sharper and clearer mind actually helps create better fantasy. However, fantasy relies on people wanting to know and perceive truth; if humanity ever loses its desire for facts, fantasy will wither and become unhealthy delusion. This is because true creative fantasy is built upon a solid understanding of how the real world works, even though it isn't strictly limited by it. For example, the imaginative tales of Lewis Carroll are founded on logic, and stories about frog-kings could only exist because we understand the difference between frogs and humans.

quote:
Then the boat turned towards me, and stayed its pace, and floated slowly by within my hand's reach, yet I durst not handle it. It waded deep, as if it were heavily burdened, and it seemed to me as it passed under my gaze that it was almost filled with clear water, from which came the light; and lapped in the water a warrior lay asleep.

A broken sword was on his knee. I saw many wounds on him. it was Boromir, my brother, dead. I knew his gear, his sword, his beloved face. One thing only I missed: his horn. One thing only I knew not: a fair belt, as it were of linked golden leaves, about his waist.

Boromir! I cried. Where is thy horn? Whither goest thou? O Boromir! But he was gone. The boat turned into the stream and passed glimmering on into the night. Dreamlike it was, and yet no dream, for there was no waking.

quote:
Is it not a strange fate that we should suffer so much fear and doubt for so small a thing? So small a thing! And I have seen it only for an instant in the house of Elrond! Could I not have a sight of it again?"

Frodo looked up. His heart went suddenly cold. He caught the strange gleam in Boromir's eyes, yet his face was still kind and friendly. "It is best that it should lie hidden," he answered.

"As you wish. I care not." said Boromir.
prompt_template:
Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Is it not a strange fate that we should suffer so much fear and doubt for so small a thing? So small a thing! And I have seen it only for an instant in the house of Elrond! Could I not have a sight of it again?"

Frodo looked up. His heart went suddenly cold. He caught the strange gleam in Boromir's eyes, yet his face was still kind and friendly. "It is best that it should lie hidden," he answered.

"As you wish. I care not." said Boromir.
summary: Boromir expresses his bewilderment that something so small (referring to the One Ring) could cause so much fear and trouble, and he reveals a strong desire to see it again, even though he only glimpsed it briefly. Frodo immediately senses the dangerous temptation in Boromir's words, feeling a cold dread and noticing a strange, longing look in Boromir's eyes despite his outwardly friendly face. Frodo firmly replies that it's best for the object to remain hidden. Boromir then dismissively says he doesn't care, but his earlier words and Frodo's reaction suggest his underlying desire for the Ring hasn't truly vanished.

quote:
I met a lot of things on the way that astonished me. Tom Bombadil I knew already; but I had never been to Bree. Strider sitting in the corner at the inn was a shock, and I had no more idea who he was than had Frodo. The Mines of Moria had been a mere name; and of Lothloriene no word had reached my mortal ears till I came there. Far away I knew there were the Horselords on the confines of an ancient Kingdom of Men, but Fanghorn Forest was an unforeseen adventure. I had never heard of the House of Eorl nor of the Stewards of Gondor. Most disquieting of all, Saruman had never been revealed to me, and I was as mystefied as Frodo at Gandalf's failure to appear on September 22.

J.R.R. Tolkien, in a letter to W.H. Auden, June 7, 1955
prompt_template:
Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: I met a lot of things on the way that astonished me. Tom Bombadil I knew already; but I had never been to Bree. Strider sitting in the corner at the inn was a shock, and I had no more idea who he was than had Frodo. The Mines of Moria had been a mere name; and of Lothloriene no word had reached my mortal ears till I came there. Far away I knew there were the Horselords on the confines of an ancient Kingdom of Men, but Fanghorn Forest was an unforeseen adventure. I had never heard of the House of Eorl nor of the Stewards of Gondor. Most disquieting of all, Saruman had never been revealed to me, and I was as mystefied as Frodo at Gandalf's failure to appear on September 22.

J.R.R. Tolkien, in a letter to W.H. Auden, June 7, 1955
summary: J.R.R. Tolkien explains that as he wrote *The Lord of the Rings*, he was often surprised by his own story. He discovered many elements and characters as he went along, rather than having them all planned out from the beginning. He felt the same shock and mystery as his characters, like Frodo. For instance, he hadn't known about places like Bree or the Mines of Moria, nor did he initially know about characters like Strider or the evil wizard Saruman. Even major plot points, like Gandalf's unexpected absence, were as much a mystery to him as they were to Frodo.
